subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. This morning
I happened to notice an email from my old
friend Jack Sarfatti, the physicist who
helped contribute a section on physics
and consciousness back in the 1975
edition of my book, The Roots of
Consciousness. As I've mentioned a
few times before, this is the first time
in a popular book that the idea that
psychic phenomenon might be mediated by
what is known in physics as Bell's
Theorem, or sometimes it's now commonly
thought of as quantum entanglement,
might be a way to explain psychic
phenomena. Now, that explanation, it's
certainly not dead, but it has now many
years later, we can say it is far from
accepted. I can say this, a great
deal of Sarfatti's thinking along this
area has been popularized in the book,
How The Hippies Saved Physics. But this
morning, the email from Jack Sarfatti was
in reference to a talk that had been
given [on June 8, 2018, in Las Vegas], by another
friend of mine, Hal Puthoff, who is now
an officer in an organization called
Toward the Stars. Hal Puthoff is very
well known for his research in remote
viewing. He's also very well known for
his theoretical work on what is known as
zero point energy in physics, the energy
that exists in a pure vacuum. Arthur C.
Clarke even praised this work very
highly in one of his books. But the
point of all of this is that Puthoff
commented on a video published in the
New York Times last December, in 2017.
It's a video taken from a Navy jet
fighter, a hornet
I believe, taking off from the USS
Nimitz aircraft carrier,
of a, apparently a UFO, an unidentified flying
object. Puthoff's analysis of that
video - and I'm linking to that video now
for those of you who might be intrigued -
Puthoff's analysis is that this object
was not human made. He doesn't go
so far as to say it's extraterrestrial.
He just says we don't have the
technology to do what that object was
videotaped doing. So now, why is this
significant in the context of Jack
Sarfatti? Here's where the story gets
interesting, because you see, this has
been published long ago in my book The
Roots of Consciousness. For people who
follow Jack Sarfatti,
this is a well-known story, but many of
you watching this video may not know.
When he was a youngster, I think around
13 years of age, growing up in Brooklyn,
New York, on one occasion he began
receiving a phone call, I think maybe
even a series of phone calls with a
metallic sounding voice, saying to him,
"This is a computer aboard a UFO and I'm
contacting you because you are soon
going to be in contact with people. You
are going to become a scientist, and you
will be working with people who are
going to help uncover these mysteries." So,
subsequently, Sarfatti has had an
interest in physics and consciousness.
He's been a gadfly. Jack Sarfatti has
managed to insult or irritate almost
everybody I know and yet most people, in
spite of his sometimes abrasive
personality, are kind of fond of the guy.
I have to admit, I am. I like Jack because
he's a provocateur in some ways. He's
been developing an unusual theory of
consciousness. It
is based on what he thinks of as, I guess
what you could call the early Bohm (David
Bohm) interpretation of quantum theory at
a time when Bohm was working under the
influence of Albert Einstein.
Einstein didn't really accept the
Copenhagen interpretation of quantum
theory. He's famous for saying, "God doesn't
play dice with the Universe." In other
words, it's not just a statistical
theory based on probabilities. Instead,
Einstein wanted to see more of a
mechanist theory, and Bohm's early work
was in that direction. Sarfatti is now
picking up on this early work in which
basically - and I'm not a physicist, I hope
you understand, but I'm going to try and
interpret this for you - that instead
of saying as the Copenhagen
interpretation of quantum theory states,
that it's the observer who collapses the
wave function in quantum physics
experiments. So, the Schrodinger
probability cloud becomes defined now as
specific observations, a particle is no
longer spread over a probability field,
but it's here or it's here. Now, the
Copenhagen interpretation would say it's
actually the observer who does that. The
interpretation in the early Bohm work
is that the particles are guided by a
pilot wave. It's the pilot wave that
forms the probability cloud. The particle
was always a particle. According to
Sarfatti - and this is where it gets very
technical and I may be miss speaking -
something about the pilot wave itself,
that is consciousness. Qualia would be
the philosophical term for awareness of
color, shape, form, sound, conscious
awareness. It's built-in deeply into the
system according to Sarfatti and he
believes that he has a testable model, a
model which he would call Popper
falsifiable, meaning
that according to the great philosopher
of science Karl Popper, his notion of
consciousness is precisely defined and
can be tested and disproven, falsified in
an experiment. If his idea is correct,
Sarfatti claims we can use that
knowledge to build conscious computers.
Now, why would we want to build conscious
computers? For space travel. You see, a
human body will probably never be able
to travel to the stars. It'll take too
long, the accelerations may be too great,
the radiation in outer space. Our
biological systems are probably just
fine for traveling around our part of
the solar system, but when it comes to
reaching out, to traveling across the
galaxy or to travel even to other
galaxies, it may be necessary to build
conscious robots, in effect, silicon-based
systems that can sustain space travel in
ways that our carbon-based bodies cannot.
Sarfatti even speculates that we could
upload our consciousness into these
silicon-based conscious systems so that
we would, in effect,
completely change our physiology and
therefore be capable of space travel. Now,
most people would say that this idea is
absurd on the face of it and many of
them would say so because of Jack
Sarfatti's abrasiveness towards them. For one
thing, the mainstream interpretation of
quantum physics really is the
Copenhagen interpretation, not the early
work of David Bohm, influenced by Albert
Einstein. So, all of the work in Bell's
Theorem, as a matter of fact, and I've
talked about it in earlier "In Presence"
segments, favors the
conventional interpretation of Bell's
Theorem in quantum theory. Einstein
objected to it. He says it would lead to
spooky action at a distance so that
can't be. But in fact, it's now well
confirmed: spooky action at a distance is
real. So, one reason for dismissing
Sarfatti's argument is precisely that, that
the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum
physics does seem to be the correct one.
Sarfatti argues vehemently that Bohr, the
great physicist Niels Bohr from
Copenhagen, who is really the father of
the Copenhagen interpretation, Sarfatti
believes that Bohr was wrong. All I
can say is this, if Sarfatti is correct, if
his precise definition of
consciousness can be confirmed and if
that actually would enable us to build
conscious computers, like Data in Star
Trek for example, well it opens up a vast
realm of possibility. I think some
people are saying at least this about
Jack Sarfatti's work. He is sort of an
internet gadfly, as I've mentioned. He hasn't
published anything in a mainstream
physics journal for a long time, but
people who are looking carefully at his
work would say this. It's not obviously
false. It does seem in theory to be
testable. It may not work out, but at
least in principle it could be tested
and it would open up a vast new realm of
applications, especially in the field of
conscious computers, if true. So, it's
worth paying attention to. And of course,
now this recent UFO sighting, I think
the original video goes back to about
2004, but still that's relatively
recent,
and it's a very high-quality video in
the sense that it was captured on a
jet fighter, a hornet jet fighter, with
the most advanced video and computerized
tracking equipment for looking at
potential enemy aircraft in the sky and
so on. Hal Puthoff's analysis of
it, I have to accept as being a very
sophisticated interpretation based on
the fact that I've known Hal Puthoff
for decades. He's a very serious
scientist looking into these matters. So,
in a way you could think backwards about
it and say, "Yes, UFOs are here. How did
they get here?" It would make sense if
they're coming from extraterrestrial
sources, which is the
implication of Puthoff's analysis. If
that's the case, or other dimensional,
then the prospect that these UFOs are in
effect being manned by conscious robots
of some sort makes sense. Sarfatti's
childhood recollections of having been
contacted himself by conscious computers,
which he holds to after many, many
decades also begins to come into
alignment with all of his other thinking.
It's certainly food for thought and I'll
leave you with that. Thanks once again
for being with me.
